raw_text:
UK pledges £1bn to vaccine effort
 
 UK Chancellor Gordon Brown has offered £960m ($1.8bn) over 15 years to an international scheme aiming to boost vaccination and immunisation schemes.
 
 In a speech, he called for action to reach the 2000 Millennium Declaration goals of halving global poverty and tackling child mortality rates. Mr Brown has just returned from a tour of African nations. The £1bn commitment is part of a five-point plan on debt relief, trade, aid, education and health.
 
 The chancellor was speaking at an event jointly organised by the UK's Department for International Development and the UN Development Programme on Wednesday. Mr Brown welcomed news that the Bill Gates Foundation and Norway are joining up to put an extra £0.53bn ($1bn ) into the Global Alliance for Vaccines and Immunisation (Gavi). Britain, France, Gavi and the Gates Foundation have drawn up proposals to apply the principles of the International Finance Facility (IFF) to the area of immunisation. That could see donors making long-term, legally binding financial commitments which can then be used as collateral for raising extra funds from international capital markets. As well as pledging £960m over 15 years to the immunisation IFF, Britain urged other donors to contribute.
 
 If Gavi could increase its funding for immunisation by an extra £4bn ($7.4bn) over 10 years, then an extra five million lives could have been saved by 2015 and five million thereafter, Mr Brown argued. Campaign groups including Friends of the Earth, the World Development Movement, and War on Want said UK government policy on free trade was a major barrier to fighting poverty. War on Want's John Hilary said: "Compassionate rhetoric cannot disguise the reality of the government's neo-liberal policies. "As long as Mr Blair and Mr Brown continue to push free trade and privatisation on developing countries, more and more people will be pushed deeper into poverty, not lifted out of it."

UK offers £1bn to vaccine effort
The UK has pledged £960m over 15 years to an international scheme to boost vaccination efforts.
Chancellor Gordon Brown called for action to address global issues such as halving global poverty and reducing child mortality rates.
llama3.2:3b: UK Chancellor Gordon Brown pledged £960m ($1.8bn) over 15 years to the Global Alliance for Vaccines and Immunisation (Gavi), aiming to boost vaccination efforts globally, as part of a five-point plan on debt relief, trade, aid, education, and health. The UK's contribution was welcomed by Gavi and Bill Gates Foundation, which added £0.53bn ($1bn) and pledged to increase immunization funding by $7.4bn over 10 years, potentially saving five million lives by 2015.

This commitment is part of a five-point plan focused on debt relief, trade, aid, education, and health.  UK officials are also exploring the potential of long-term financial commitments (like the International Finance Facility) for immunization funding.  Campaign groups criticize UK free trade policies as a barrier to poverty reduction.

This commitment is part of a five-point plan aimed at reaching Millennium Development Goals related to halving global poverty and reducing child mortality. Brown also called for increased international funding and pledged additional support from Bill Gates Foundation and Norway.

smollm:1.7b:
The UK has pledged £960 million over 15 years to an international scheme aimed at boosting vaccination and immunisation schemes. The chancellor is calling for action to reach the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) of halving global poverty and tackling child mortality rates. He returned from a tour of African nations, where he met with leaders and civil society groups. The £1 billion commitment is part of a five-point plan on debt relief, trade, aid, education and health.
The chancellor welcomed news that the Bill Gates Foundation and Norway are joining up to put an extra £0.53bn into the Global Alliance for Vaccines and Immunisation (Gavi). Britain, France, Gavi and the Gates Foundation have drawn up proposals to apply the principles of the International Finance Facility (IFF) to the area of immunisation. That could see donors making long-term, legally binding financial commitments which can then be used as collateral for raising extra funds from international capital markets. As well as pledging £960 million over 15 years to the immunisation IFF, Britain urged other donors to contribute.
If Gavi could increase its funding for immunisation by an extra £4bn over 10 years, then an extra five million lives could have been saved by 2015 and five million thereafter, War on Want's John Hilary said. "Compassionate rhetoric cannot disguise the reality of the government's neo-liberal policies," he added. As long as Mr Blair and Mr Brown continue to push free trade and privatisation on developing countries, more and more people will be pushed deeper into poverty, not lifted out of it.

Brown is against continued free trade, stating that neo-liberal policies prevent more from entering the economy without support, leading to increased poverty.

So, I need to condense all this information into a clear summary without adding any explanations or formatting. The focus should be on the main points: UK's £1bn commitment, Gavi's plan, potential savings if funding is extended, campaign concerns about free trade, and Brown's opposition.

UK has pledged £1 billion for vaccine efforts over 15 years, aimed at addressing poverty and child mortality as part of the Millennium Declaration goals. Chancellor Gordon Brown is speaking at a joint event with the UN Development Programme and Department for International Development, welcoming Gavi's partnership with Bill Gates and Norway to invest an additional £0.53 billion in immunisation. This could enable donors to make long-term financial commitments to secure funding for 10 years. If Gavi increases its immunisation funding by £4 billion over 10 years, it could save 5 million lives each year and the same number thereafter. Campaigns like Friends of the Earth and World Development Movement are concerned about free trade policies hindering poverty alleviation efforts. They argue that such policies push more people into poverty rather than lifting them out of it. Chancellor Brown is against continued free trade, stating that neo-liberal policies prevent more from entering the economy without support, exacerbating poverty.
tinyllama:1.1b: UK Chancellor Gordon Brown offered a £960m ($1.8bn) commitment over 15 years to support an international scheme aiming to boost immunization and reduce child mortality rates. He also called for the creation of a new partnership between the UK, Norway, Bill Gate's Foundation and the Global Alliance for Vaccination and Immunisation (Gavi), which has proposed applying principles from the International Finance Facility for Immunization to other areas like immunizations. If Gavi could raise an extra £4bn ($7.4bn) over 10 years, it could save millions of lives and increase access to vaccinations by five million. The campaign groups mentioned above called UK government policy on free trade a major barrier to fighting poverty, with War on Want's John Hilary stating that compassionate measures cannot disguise neo-liberal policies.
tinydolphin:1.1b:
The UK has offered £960m ($1.8bn) over 15 years to boost vaccination and immunization efforts in countries around the world under an ambitious five-point plan announced by UK Chancellor Gordon Brown during a tour of African nations. This move is part of a broader strategy to halve poverty, combat child mortality, and address global health goals, as outlined in the 2000 Millennium Declaration. The £1bn commitment is part of a five-point plan on debt relief, trade, aid, education, and health, jointly organized by the UK's Department for International Development (DFID) and the UN Development Programme (UNDP). 

Britain, France, Gavi, and the Gates Foundation are now seeking other donors to contribute legally binding financial commitments as part of a Global Alliance for Vaccines and Immunisation (GAVI) initiative. If Gavi could increase its funding by an extra £4bn ($7.4bn) over 10 years, then an additional five million lives could have been saved by 2015 and five million thereafter, according to Brown's speech. The plan aims to reduce the global burden of diseases and promote health in developing countries.

Campaign groups such as Friends of the Earth, World Development Movement, and War on Want argue that UK government policy on free trade is a major obstacle to fighting poverty. They say that the government should focus on policies that improve living standards for everyone, not further enrich corporations at the expense of workers' rights and communities.
phi:2.7b: The UK Chancellor Gordon Brown has pledged £960m over 15 years to an international scheme that aims to boost vaccination and immunization. This comes as part of a five-point plan for debt relief, trade, aid, education, and health. Mr Brown also called on other donors to contribute, with the hope that this increased funding could save up to 5 million lives by 2015. However, campaign groups have criticized the UK government's policy on free trade and privatization, arguing that it perpetuates poverty in developing countries.

If Gavi can increase its funding for immunization by an extra £4bn ($7.4bn) over 10 years, then an extra five million lives could be saved by 2015 and five million thereafter. Campaign groups including Friends of the Earth, the World Development Movement, and War on Want say UK government policy on free trade is a major barrier to fighting poverty.

Critics argue that UK government policy on free trade is a major barrier to fighting poverty.

The initiative, part of a broader five-point plan on debt relief, trade, aid, education, and health, involves using long-term financial commitments as collateral to raise extra funds. granite3.1-dense:2b: UK Chancellor Gordon Brown announced a £960 million (approximately $1.8 billion) 15-year commitment to enhance global vaccination and immunisation programs as part of his five-point plan for development assistance, focusing on debt relief, trade, aid, education, and health. This pledge is in response to the UK's recent tour of African nations and aligns with the Global Alliance for Vaccines and Immunisation (Gavi). Governments, including Britain, France, Gavi, and the Bill Gates Foundation, are proposing to apply International Finance Facility (IFF) principles to immunisation financing, enabling long-term, legally binding commitments that could attract additional funds from international capital markets. If Gavi secured an extra £4 billion ($7.4 billion) over ten years, it could save five million lives by 2015 and maintain that impact thereafter, according to Brown's estimates. Critics, such as War on Want, argue that the UK's free trade policies exacerbate poverty in developing countries rather than alleviating it.
reference: Mr Brown welcomed news that the Bill Gates Foundation and Norway are joining up to put an extra £0.53bn ($1bn ) into the Global Alliance for Vaccines and Immunisation (Gavi).UK Chancellor Gordon Brown has offered £960m ($1.8bn) over 15 years to an international scheme aiming to boost vaccination and immunisation schemes.If Gavi could increase its funding for immunisation by an extra £4bn ($7.4bn) over 10 years, then an extra five million lives could have been saved by 2015 and five million thereafter, Mr Brown argued."As long as Mr Blair and Mr Brown continue to push free trade and privatisation on developing countries, more and more people will be pushed deeper into poverty, not lifted out of it."Britain, France, Gavi and the Gates Foundation have drawn up proposals to apply the principles of the International Finance Facility (IFF) to the area of immunisation.Campaign groups including Friends of the Earth, the World Development Movement, and War on Want said UK government policy on free trade was a major barrier to fighting poverty.
